Not quite, although they are similar. A prediction is just that, a prediction as to what will happen under a given set of circumstances. It can be useful for testing hypotheses. A hypothesis is a proposed explanation for some observed phenomenon. So basically, a hypothesis is what you think is happening and the underlying mechanism. A prediction is what you get by using this hypothesis and applying it to a given situation. For instance, with gravity, suppose you were Isaac Newton a few years ago. Your hypothesis would be that objects exert a force on another that attracts objects based on mass. Using this hypothesis, you could make a prediction that a ball dropped from a certain height would accelerate at this rate. By testing the prediction against observations, you can test the underlying hypothesis.

Hypotheses are formalisms of the Scientific Method. A hypothesis is a proposed model of cause, classification, or localization that could be experimentally eliminated by contradiction. For example, suppose you are looking for your lost car keys (as a test for localization). You would synthesize places to look (i.e., hypotheses), which you would experimentally eliminate until you found your car keys. ‘Prediction’ is a broader term. A prediction is a model of future events. A prediction need not necessarily even be scientific; e.g., you could create predictive models in part by flipping a coin.
